title.justification: This title captures the content and context of the paper, which is documentation related to the UK Biobank project focused on brain imaging.

extractions.description: This document is the primary guide for the brain imaging component of the UK Biobank study. It outlines the protocols, processing pipelines, and guidelines for data usage in brain imaging analysis within the UK Biobank dataset.

type.justification: The document primarily provides an in-depth theoretical framework for brain imaging, detailing imaging protocols and processing methodologies rather than empirical research results.
type.quote: This documentation describes the brain imaging component of the UK Biobank prospective epidemiological study.

name.justification: The primary focus of the document revolves around protocols, acquisitions, and processing related to brain imaging within the UK Biobank.
name.quote: This documentation describes the brain imaging component of the UK Biobank prospective epidemiological study.

name.justification: The document discusses various neuroimaging techniques, including MRI modalities used in the study.
name.quote: The brain imaging data acquisition primarily includes 6 modalities, covering structural, diffusion and functional imaging.

name.justification: FLIRT is referenced in the context of pre-processing steps such as image alignment across different modalities.
name.quote: The T2 image is linearly aligned to the T1 using FLIRT, and the resulting transform is then combined with various transforms derived from the T1.

is_contributed.justification: FLIRT is an established tool used in the processing pipeline, not introduced by this documentation.
is_contributed.quote: The T2 image is linearly aligned to the T1 using FLIRT...

is_executed.justification: FLIRT is actively used in the pipeline for image processing applications, indicating its execution.
is_executed.quote: The T2 image is linearly aligned to the T1 using FLIRT...

is_compared.justification: There is no mention of FLIRT being compared numerically against other models in the documentation.
is_compared.quote: The T2 image is linearly aligned to the T1 using FLIRT...

referenced_paper_title.value: A global optimisation method for robust affine registration of brain images
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper provides details about the FLIRT tool that is used in the pipeline.
referenced_paper_title.quote: [Jenkinson and Smith, 2001] Jenkinson, M. and Smith, S. (2001). A global optimisation method for robust affine registration of brain images.

name.justification: ICA is used in the preprocessing of the rfMRI data, which is part of the imaging analysis pipeline.
name.quote: Structured artefacts are removed by ICA+FIX processing (Independent Component Analysis followed by FMRIB’s ICA-based X-noiseifier).

is_contributed.justification: ICA is a well-established computational technique, not specifically contributed in this document.
is_contributed.quote: Structured artefacts are removed by ICA+FIX processing (Independent Component Analysis followed by FMRIB’s ICA-based X-noiseifier).

is_executed.justification: ICA is applied to remove artefacts from the rfMRI data, showing active use in the process.
is_executed.quote: Structured artefacts are removed by ICA+FIX processing (Independent Component Analysis followed by FMRIB’s ICA-based X-noiseifier).

is_compared.justification: There are no indications of a numerical comparison for ICA against other methods in the paper.
is_compared.quote: Structured artefacts are removed by ICA+FIX processing (Independent Component Analysis followed by FMRIB’s ICA-based X-noiseifier).

referenced_paper_title.value: Fast and robust fixed-point algorithms for independent component analysis
referenced_paper_title.justification: This paper discusses the algorithms behind ICA, which are utilized in the processing pipeline.
referenced_paper_title.quote: [Hyvärinen, 1999] Hyvärinen, A. (1999). Fast and robust fixed-point algorithms for independent component analysis.

name.justification: The dataset is central to the research, providing the subject data and context for the brain imaging analysis documented.
name.quote: This documentation describes the brain imaging component of the UK Biobank prospective epidemiological study.

referenced_paper_title.value: Multimodal population brain imaging in the UK Biobank prospective epidemiological study
referenced_paper_title.justification: This paper is a primary citation for using UK Biobank's brain imaging data.
referenced_paper_title.quote:
Primary citation for brain imaging in UK Biobank:
Multimodal population brain imaging in the UK Biobank prospective epidemiological study.

name.justification: FSL is referenced multiple times as part of the image processing pipeline, providing essential tools for analysis.
name.quote: ...using publicly available image processing tools, primarily taken from FSL (the FMRIB Software Library [Jenkinson et al., 2012], version 5.0.10).

referenced_paper_title.justification: This paper provides an overview of FSL and its functionalities.
referenced_paper_title.quote: [Jenkinson et al., 2012] Jenkinson, M., Beckmann, C., Behrens, T., Woolrich, M., and Smith, S. (2012). FSL.

name.justification: FreeSurfer is noted for its use in surface modelling and segmentation within the pipeline.
name.quote: In addition, certain aspects of the analysis were carried out using FreeSurfer [Dale et al., 1999] version 6.0.

referenced_paper_title.value: Cortical Surface-Based Analysis I: Segmentation and Surface Reconstruction
referenced_paper_title.justification: This referenced paper introduces the technique utilized by FreeSurfer for surface analysis.
referenced_paper_title.quote: [Dale et al., 1999] Dale, A., Fischl, B., and Sereno, M. (1999). Cortical surface-based analysis I: Segmentation and surface reconstruction.
